Award.AwardTitle: Curricular Learning to Optimize Science Education: C.L.O.S.E. the Gap in Introductory Biology

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is testing the hypothesis that a highly structured course design, developed and tested in one quarter of the 3-quarter introductory biology sequence for majors at the University of Washington (UW), can be implemented by instructors who teach introductory biology at three institutions diverse as to mission (from community college to an R1 institution) and class size (from 40 to 700).

Intellectual merit: Recent work by this group (Haak et al (2011) Science 332 1213-1216,http://www.sciencemag.org/content/332/6034/1213.abstract) has shown that the highly structured course design--which combines intensive active learning in lecture-free class sessions with daily and weekly formative assessments in the form of on-line quizzes--increased overall student performance and lowered the achievement gap between students from disadvantaged versus advantaged backgrounds.

Broadening participation: The current goal is to determine if the course materials can produce similar results in the hands of other instructors, working with other student populations (at Eastern Michigan and Eastern Washington Universities and at Everett (Washington) Community College). The course content at these institutions overlaps completely or substantially with Biology 180 at the University of Washington, the course that is already supported with evidence-based, high-structure materials. When the project is completed, data will be available from institutions ranging from selective to open enrollment, from R1s to community colleges, and with class enrollments from 700 to 40. The efficacy of the materials in the hands of an instructor with minimal teaching experience-specifically--a post-doctoral research associate or a newly hired, tenure-track research faculty member of the UW Department of Biology--is also being investigated within the same course to enable comparison of materials on performance in the same student population, when delivered by experienced versus inexperienced faculty.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In undergraduate science education, "high structure" course designs require students to prepare for class, do intensive active learning exercises (problem-solving) in class, and then follow-up with frequent homework assignments or practice exams, prior to actual exams. Research on introductory biology classes at the University of Washington has shown that the high structure format leads to better performance by all students when compared to the same course taught in the traditional lecture format, and that students who come from disadvantaged backgrounds gain disproportionate benefits. As a result, changing courses to a high-structure format can reduce achievement gaps that have prevented students from disadvantaged backgrounds from pursuing careers in the sciences.

The purpose of this project was to answer the question: Can high structure course designs be used successfully by other instructors and at other institutions? By adding elements of a high structure course to existing courses at an array of colleges and universities and tracking student performance before and after, the researchers found that the answer is a resounding "Yes." In at least one case, achievement gaps traditionally experienced by African-American students were cut in half, with complete elimination of achievement gaps for students who are the first in their family to attend college.  At all four colleges and universities where experiments took place, the researchers found that adding additional structure to an existing course led to an increase in performance for all students. In other words, the high structure approach to teaching science "travels"--it has the potential to be used successfully at all institution types and by any instructor. This is an important contribution to knowledge, as colleges and universities move to embrace what has been called "scientific teaching" or "evidence-based teaching."

This result is important to society at large, as well, because leading educators and policymakers have called for a dramatic increase in the percentage of students who are retained in science majors and go on to have the credentials and skills required to pursue a successful career in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics. One of the major reasons that students who are interested in pursuing science leave and switch majors is poor performance in introductory courses. The higher average performance by all students in high structure courses should encourage more students to remain in science majors, and lowering achievement gaps will help improve equality of opportunity for all students--regardless of their family background.
